Text: I want to take that $716 billion you've cut and put it back into Medicare.
And finally, he said he's going to have a novel health care plan.

But the right answer is not to have the federal government take over health care and start mandating to the providers across America, telling a patient and a doctor what kind of treatment they can have.
Now last week I guess it was Donna Shalala said well we'll cut Medicare a hundred billion and appoint a commission.
We've got to get costs down, increase value, emphasize wellness.
We have to repeal and replace Obamacare.
Well, that's exactly the commitment that was made to the American people in 1980: He would never reduce benefits.
I'd rather be able to have an insurance company.
But let me just say the American Hospital Association said that the budget I vetoed could have closed 700 hospitals.
Our funding for recovery is up, recovering the addicts.
You can keep what you have today, keep a high deductible, keep high premiums, keep a high co-pay, keep low benefits.
Now, we also have people sicker because they don't have health insurance.
If you like your high premiums, you keep them.
If they did have coverage, insurance companies might impose an arbitrary limit.
Number three, it puts in place an unelected board that's going to tell people ultimately what kind of treatments they can have.
Well, Jim, the FDA took 12 years, and I do support that decision.
And we control private and public health care costs.
Compared to what's going on in Europe, as the New England Medical Journal said, they're starting from a very low rate.
[Laughter] The fact of it is: The President's budget sought to cut Social Security by 25 percent.

Well, this is another fundamental difference that I have with the vice president, just as I do in the case of health care for 37 million members of working families in this country who don't have health insurance.
Pay $1 an hour for your labor, have no health care -- that's the most expensive single element in making the car.
To giving every American a $5,000 refundable tax credit and go out and get the health insurance you want rather than mandates and fines for small businesses, as Senator Obama's plan calls for.
But it compels nobody to have insurance who does not want it.
But Obamacare has to go.
I've had the best healthcare from government hospitals, Army hospitals and I know its importance, but we've got to fix it.

And we're beginning with drug education and prevention beginning in the early elementary grades in every elementary school in our state, and that's the kind of effort we need in every elementary school in the United States of America.
And so we took the right action and didn't allow contaminated medicine into our country.
It takes on the pharmaceutical industry, which in some cases charges us 10 times more for the same prescription drugs sold abroad as sold here.

And throughout all that time the people I have fought for have been the middle-class families, and I have been willing to stand up to powerful interests like the big insurance companies, the drug companies, the HMOs, the oil companies.
And so seniors will have not only a Medicare plan where the poor seniors will have prescription drugs paid for, but there will be a variety of options.
Obviously small business people want to give their employees health insurance.

They have 270 billion dollars in Medicare cuts the first education cuts in history, cut environmental enforcement by 25 percent, took away the guarantee of quality standards in nursing homes, took away the guarantee of health care for folks with disabilities.
The problem is that because the voucher wouldn't necessarily keep up with health care inflation, it was estimated that this would cost the average senior about $6,000 a year.
Copays, deductibles, prescription drug costs, and I've laid out a series of actions that we can take to try to get those costs down.
We spent a lot of money to make sure people get health care in the State of Texas, and we're doing a better job than they are at the national level for reducing uninsured.

But if our government itself is doing business with people who we know are engaged in drug profiteering and drug trafficking, if we don't understand that that sends out a very, very bad message to our young people, it's a little difficult for me to understand just how we can reach out to that youngster that I talked about and to young people like her all over the country, and say to them we want to help you.
I support a strong national patient's bill of rights.
My balanced budget plan puts ten years on the Medicare.
We should not be one of a few countries that does not have universal high-quality affordable childcare.
They're very important parts of the safety net of health care.
Most people want to see their own doctor.
The reason Social Security -- he says it gets 2%.
If you stop the drugs, nobody is going to use the drugs; so don't smoke, don't drink, don't use drugs.
All I want to do, if you've already got health care, is lower your costs.
I want to take one-half of the surplus and dedicate it to Social Security.
We haven't adequately funded veterans' care.
But I do not want to see a military involvement on the part of our -- of our troops.
Because they understand that our military is overextended under the president.
We spend more on our military than the next 10 countries combined; China, Russia, France, the United Kingdom, you name it.
I'm saying, well, this is not as tough as World War II and it's not as tough as the revolution.
Even though they had to find out they had 5,000 troops coming, they didn't even understand that.
We're continuing to increase manpower and equipment.
But I'll always remember that the best weapons are the ones that are never fired in combat, and the best soldier is one who never has to lay his life down on the field of battle.
You know, back after World War II when we had hundreds of thousands of GIs who came back from the war, we didn't sit around.
I have, obviously, supported those efforts that the United States had to go in militarily and I have opposed that I didn't think so.
There are now over 2,000 more warheads pointed at us today than there were when he was sworn in, and that does not strengthen us.
We'll be resolute, we'll be strong, and we'll wage a comprehensive war against the terrorists.
I haven't given lots of thought to NATO.
And so we need military strength, we need economic strength, we also need the right diplomatic policies.
I saw a high school that is military.

But you can't tell me that when the most troops any other country has on the ground is Great Britain, with 8,300, and below that the four others are below 4,000, and below that, there isn't anybody out of the hundreds, that we have a genuine coalition to get this job done.
We've got Guards and Reserves who are doing double duties.

Well, I am encouraged that there is an effort led by the Iraqi army, supported by Kurdish forces, and also given the help and advice from the number of special forces and other Americans on the ground.
I didn't say I would bring troops out in six months.
General Shinsheki, the Army chief of staff, said you're going to need several hundred thousand troops.
First, the Joint Chiefs of Staff went to the President, said, "Don't put those troops there.''
There are certain army bases that the act calls for that can be used in certain cases to shelter people when it's rough.
And I vowed something because I learned something from Vietnam.
We need a million-man active reserve that could be called up on an instant's notice, and that would be also trained, ready to use that type of equipment.
I also intend to double the number of special forces so that we can do the job we need to do with respect fighting the terrorists around the world.
I volunteered for the Army.
To save for Halliburton the spoils of the war, they actually issued a memorandum from the Defense Department saying, "If you weren't with us in the war, don't bother applying for any construction."

Well, I think the fact that they're facing these repeated call-ups, some of them two and three deployments, and there's a stop- loss policy that prevents people from being able to get out when their time was up, is a reflection of the bad judgment this president exercised in how he has engaged in the world and deployed our forces.
Now we have two major carrier task forces.
If we're not training engineers to make sure that they are equipped here in this country.
I think that by speaking clearly and doing what we say and not sending mixed messages, it is less likely we'll ever have to use troops.

But, I think that that is clearly related to the fact that, going back to the time when the all-volunteer Army was created in 1973 - and I worked hard for it and supported it - we simply have failed to keep pace with the cost of living.
Two-thirds of the country was a no-fly zone when we started this war.

I'm sorry, you actually -- there was a -- there was an effort on the part of the president to have a status of forces agreement, and I concurred in that, and said that we should have some number of troops that stayed on.
And so we're moving troops out of Europe and replacing it with more effective equipment.
The force must be strong enough so that the mission can be accomplished.
You know, we won that conflict in Kosovo without losing a single human life in combat, a single American life in combat.
We've changed for the first time since FDR -- since FDR we had the -- we've always had the strategy of saying we could fight in two conflicts at once.
They didn't get the tanks from this administration because we were nation building.
Oh, there were occasional snipings and sometimes some artillery fire, but we did not engage in conflict that was out of line with our mission.
And we have to keep our military strong.
And I think that we have to do it as quickly as possible, because it's been acknowledged by the commanders on the ground the situation is getting worse, not better.
Let's remember the way to win is not to retreat and not to surrender.
And we would target it especially in areas that have been either depressed or which have lost a lot of defense related jobs.
That's why, in my plan, I add two active duty divisions to the United States Army, not for Iraq, but for our general demands across the globe.
But four years ago, I told the American people and I told you I would cut taxes for middle class families.

If you want somebody who believes that we were better off eight years ago than we are now and that we ought to go back to the kind of policies that we had back then, emphasizing tax cuts mainly for the wealthy, here is your man.
No, because I'm pledged to that, and yes, some taxes have gone up.
That's twice the amount that my predecessor increased VA funding.
But I have a write-off, a lot of it's depreciation, which is a wonderful charge.

Now, I've got a plan with this new welfare reform law to work with the private sector, to give employees specific tax incentives to hire people off welfare, and to do some other things which will create more jobs in the private sector, at least a million, and move more people from welfare to work.
What I've said is I want to provide a tax cut for 95 percent of working Americans, 95 percent.
And it permits - economists on the East Coast and West think it's good - it permits the president to sort out the priorities, and we continue to grow because I will not raise taxes.
I don't know if that was a criminal issue or a paternal issue, but the fact is that it was $3 million of our taxpayers' money.
It had several tax increases phased in over a period of time -- there are two more yet to come between now and 1989.
He says he wants to give the wealthiest one percent of the people in this country a five-year $40 billion tax break, and we're going to pay for it.
Well, I think -- let's talk about taxes, because I think it's instructive.

So both those extremes grasp for advantage and the person who has to pay that expense is the middle-income family who's still working for a living and they have to pay for the rich who have privilege, and for the poor who are not working.
But, you know, if we get that tax rate from 35 percent down to 25 percent, why that $2.8 billion is on the table.
And I want to continue those tax cuts for middle-class families, and for small business.
And you supported legislation this year that's involved tax increases not once, but twice.
It's a tax that taxes people twice.
I exempt small businesses from having to pay into a kitty.
In 1983, as a result of these tax preferences, he paid a little over 12 percent, 12.8 percent in taxes.
I've been paying taxes just like you and Lord knows, I've paid my share -- over a billion in taxes.
Now, for every dollar that I propose to spend on education, he spends $5 on a tax cut for the wealthiest 1%.
If you pay any tax at all, you got tax relief.
Third, I think it's possible to gain a seven hundred million to a billion dollars through tax changes which I believe would close up loof- loopholes on dividend withholding, on expense accounts.
If you pay taxes, you are going to get a benefit.
We let families save in an IRA, withdraw tax free to pay for the cost of education and it's all paid for.
So for instance when he says, "Yours is a $5 trillion cut."
He vetoed middle class tax relief this year.
And we both want to cut taxes, the difference is who we want to cut taxes for.
And we worked together with Democrats to relieve the tax burden on the middle class and all who pay taxes in order to make sure this economy continues to grow.
He says he's going to give you tax cuts.
But the way to make sure our economy grows is not to raise taxes on small-business owners.
I worked to get $400 million just a couple of weeks ago.
You've seen, as middle-income people in this country, incomes go down $4,300 a family, even as gasoline prices have gone up $2,000.
You know, he said some time ago, he said he would forgo his tax increases if the economy was bad.
That's not true in Connecticut, family income is down.
Everybody who pays taxes ought to get some relief.
We also have capital gains now for people that invest in new small businesses and hold the investment for five years.
They don't give you all the details that tax returns would.
Middle class Americans are working harder for less money than they were making ten years ago and they're paying higher taxes.
Your home mortgage interest deduction, charity, child tax credit, and so forth, you can use those as part of filling that bucket, if you will, of deductions.
One is to raise taxes.
Paul Tsongas, a liberal senator from Massachusetts said the dumbest thing I did was to oppose the capital gains cut.
Why am I lowering taxes on the middle-class?
So when you hear "tax the rich," Mr. and Mrs. America, watch your wallet.
You just want to add an additional tax cut over the loopholes.
And inflation went down below the national average in California when we returned the money to the people and reduced Government spending.
We've gotta get this country growing again and this economy strong again or we can't bring down the deficit.
But when it comes to economic policies, essentially what you're proposing is eight more years of the same thing.
Now it seems to me that uh - as we look at the recommendations of the budget committees and our own projections, there isn't going to be any $60 billion dividend.
And tomorrow night on NBC, from 10:30 to 11 Eastern, we're going to talk about how you pay the debt down, so we're going to come right down to that one.
Well, I think the national debt affects everybody.
Senator Obama has asked for nearly $1 billion in pork-barrel earmark projects...
That, I think, is a good balance.
And there is no evidence whatsoever that that will slow down or diminish our growth.
Instead of ballooning the debt and multiplying it four times over, we have seen the debt actually begun to be paid down.
And as far as currency manipulation, the currency has actually gone up 11 percent since I've been president because we have pushed them hard.

There is no way that the recovery is even across the country, just as in the depths of the recession, there were some parts of the country that were worse off, but some that didn't even feel the pain of the recession.
So we're now on the precipice of having a potentially much better economy, but the last thing we need to do is to go back to the policies that failed us in the first place.
If you didn't balance your budget, you went out of business.

Mr. Stone, I have submitted an economic plan that I have worked out in concert with a number of fine economists in this country, all of whom approve it, and believe that over a five year projection, this plan can permit the extra spending for needed refurbishing of our defensive posture, that it can provide for a balanced budget by 1983 if not earlier, and that we can afford - along with the cuts that I have proposed in Government.

And -- and what's at stake here is one of two things, either Candy -- this blows up the deficit because keep in mind, this is just to pay for the additional spending that he's talking about, $7 trillion - $8 trillion before we even get to the deficit we already have.
I have fought to cut spending.
We're now spending 42 percent of our economy on government.
This administration may say they have a plan, but the truth is they have not even released all the money, the paltry sum of money, that Congress appropriated.
I have fought against spending.

So, we believe that as we continue to reduce the level of government spending -- the increase, rate of increase in government spending, which has come down from 17 to 6 percent, and, at the same time, as the growth in the economy increases the revenues the Government gets, without raising taxes, those two lines will meet.
But we now have an economy that, for the first time -- well, let's put it this way: In the first half of 1980, gross national product was down a minus 3.7 percent.
You can't have an economy that over the last three years keeps slowing down its growth rate.
I believe instead of doing that, we should concentrate our aid in long-term loans which these people can pay back either in hard money or in local currency.
And if we did that, we'd have more consumption ability in America, which is what we need right now in order to kick our economy into gear.
First, we have to build an economy that works for everyone, not just those at the top.

We've got declining crime rates, two million fewer people on welfare rolls before welfare reform passed, and a 50 percent increase in child support and a crime bill with 60 death penalties and 100,000 police and the assault weapons ban.

Let me say, if Senator Dole mentioned this, I just signed a bill that we got through Congress to increase the amount of pay increase we could give for military personnel and to make sure the pay increase this year was above the rate of inflation.

Bringing down our deficit by adding $7 trillion of tax cuts and military spending that our military is not asking for, before we even get to the debt that we currently have, that is not going to make us more competitive.
I want to increase spending 14 percent, that's how simple it is.
If you look at our numbers right now, we are doing phenomenally.
Would fathers and mothers feel proud of themselves if they loaded their children with debts like this nation is now -- over a trillion dollars on the shoulders of our children?
Right now we spend about $300 billion a year on defense, the Japanese spend around 30 billion in Asia, the Germans spend around 30 billion in Europe.
What we've said is to states, we'll give you more money if you initiate reforms.

When we have a country that's doing so badly, that's being ripped off by every single country in the world, it's the kind of thinking that our country needs, because everybody -- Lester, we have a trade deficit with all of the countries that we do business with, of almost $800 billion a year.
When the -- when the president of Iraq -- excuse me, of Iran, Ahmadinejad, says that our debt makes us not a great country, that's a frightening thing.
So seventy percent of our debt is five years or less.

I simply think that when we are confronting a budget deficit this year - and this fiscal year will end in about 10 days, and we are confronted with the possibility of a deficit of $60 billion, perhaps as much as $63 billion - that that simply would be irresponsible.
In 1974, we had the worst recession, the deepest and most penetrating recession since the Second World War.
And I think we'll have some decrease in our disbursements.
We can get this economy going again.

Of the 3 of us, I have balanced a government budget 12 times, I have offered and passed campaign finance reform, offered, pushed for and passed in public referendum lobbyist restrictions, done the kinds of things you have to do to get legislators together not only to establish consensus but to challenge them to change.
Mr. Bush wants to spend billions on Star Wars.
I think most of the economic growth that has taken place is a result of ingenuity and hard work and entrepreneurship and that's the role of goverment to encourage that.
And I have budgeted for that.

It's my - my opinion that the private sector, where five out of six jobs are, where you have permanent jobs, with the opportunity for advancement, is a better place than make-work jobs under the program recommended by the Congress.
Donald Trump is a small business.
That would break the auto industry and throw a lot of people out of work.
That is a plan that has been analyzed by independent experts which said that it could produce 10 million new jobs.
We need to encourage business, create jobs, not spread the wealth around.
And we're still losing a lot of auto jobs, in my judgment, because we don't have a national economic strategy that will build the industrial base of this country.
The reason incomes are down is because unemployment is so high.
We have to stop our companies from leaving the United States and, with it, firing all of their people.
They produce the most jobs.
We've had 4 years where we've produced no private sector jobs.
We have now employed eighty-eight million people in America, the largest number in the history of the United States.
And I think it depends in great measure on what we do here in this country.
These make-work, temporary jobs - dead end as they are - are not the kind of jobs that we want for our people.
The secretary said very strongly about working with -- we've been working with them for many years, and we have the greatest mess anyone's ever seen.
We have to do a much better job at keeping our jobs.
That's after losing 5 million jobs.

We live in a world where what you earn depends on what you can learn, where the average 18- year-old will change jobs 8 times in a lifetime and where none of us can promise any of you that what you now do for a living is absolutely safe from now on.
They left -- fired 1,400 people.
Manufacturing went in a hole-
But it was a tremendous shift from administrative jobs into the delivery of services.
We've got ten and a half million new jobs; we've got record numbers of those new small businesses.
We've got 23 million people out of work or stopped looking for work in this country.
And so we have to understand that we can't just surrender and lose jobs year in and year out.
If you're a company in St. Louis working, trying to make jobs here, there is actually an incentive for you to go away.
And I would think, it seems to me that there are opportunities here.
...I would liquidate the industry.
Far fewer people are dying.
The trends before we -- before I got my current job were on the decline, the number of divisions were reduced.
I said that our economic plan would produce eight million jobs, we have ten and a half million new jobs.
So I do have investments, investments in new jobs, investments in education, skill training, and the opportunities for people to get ahead and stay ahead.
My path is designed in getting small businesses to grow and hire people.
We have done things to help small businesses, agriculture, and so much else.
With regard to the great progress that has been made with this Government spending, the rate of black unemployment in Detroit, Michigan, is 56%.
We've had 43 straight months with unemployment above 8 percent.
The take-home pay of a worker in this country is actually less now than it was in 1968 - measured in real dollars.
It will create tremendous numbers of new jobs.
We're beginning to see some increase in incomes, and we certainly have had a long string of increasing jobs.
Last week, as you know, the end of last week, they came out with an anemic jobs report.
Our jobs are fleeing the country.
I can't find a job.
I am not talking of scrapping.
Now there's a record: Ten and a half million more jobs, rising incomes, falling crime rates and welfare rolls, a strong America at peace.
And the take-home pay of the richest .
The real problem in this country is that most people are working hard and falling farther behind.
Dick Cheney's counted as a small business.
More than 90% of America's children go to public schools.
We need to expand education savings accounts.
Let me give you a story about public education, if I might.
And the fact that you're making an investment in higher education is critical.
I want to make sure the public school system in America keeps its promise so not one child is left behind.
But I do think that it is important for the federal government to step up and help local school districts do some of the things they need to do.
You'll get an access to life-long learning and education, help with tuition if you want to get a new skill or training.
I will do everything that I can to make sure that you have good jobs, with rising incomes, that your kids have good educations from preschool through college.
You will find that some of the worst school systems in America get the most money per student.
As I said, we have made sure that millions of young people are able to get an education that they weren't able to get before.
It's one of the best schools in Houston.
And so I believe that we've got to get the power in the hands of the teachers, not the teachers' union.
And also make sure that when they get out of college, there's a job.
Now, I have to come back in my clothes to one thing because I am passionate about education.
I think that we have to put more emphasis on early learning and pre-school.

I simply think it's wrong to take money away from programs that are helping build basic skills for kids, 90 percent of them are in the public schools; to take money away from programs that are helping fund the school lunch program, that are helping to fund the other programs, that are helping our schools to improve their standards.
Secondly, we passed a federal aid to education bill in the Senate.

So choice and competition amongst schools is one of the key elements that's already been proven in places in like New Orleans and New York City and other places, where we have charter schools, where we take good teachers and we reward them and promote them.
And our eighth graders number one in English and also in math.
And as a result, our universities are now more diverse.
I think they also know that we had a commission that came in a year ago with a recommendation on education -- on excellence in education.
This year the Republican Congress, as far as student loans went from 24 billion to 36 billion over the next six years.

And for all the rest of the parents in America who are wondering about their kids going to the school or anywhere else in the world, what kind of world they're going to grow up in, let me look you in the eye and say to you: I defended this country as a young man in war, and I will defend it as president of the United States.
Secondly, I support federal aid to education and federal aid for teachers' salaries.
You're not for school choice, you can't be for school choice, because this is that special interest money again.

But when we find children trapped in schools that will not change and will not teach, instead of saying oh, this is okay in America just to shuffle poor kids through schools, there has to be a consequence.
On pay for teachers, on all these categories, Arkansas is right near the very bottom.
And yet the president who talks about No Child Left Behind refused to fully fund -- by $28 billion -- that particular program so you can make a difference in the lives of those young people.
We've increased Pell Grants by a million students.
Entertainment industry, people involved in the schools, education.
I can't begin to pay back my student loans."
That's right at the middle class.
We've expanded Pell Grants for millions of people, including millions of young women, all across the country.
An economy with 50 percent of kids graduating from college that can't finds a job, or a college level job, that's not what we have to have.
You can't have kids coming out of college, half of them can't find a job today, or a job that's commensurate with their college degree.
I don't fault the President or the vice president for sending their children to private schools or better schools.
We have a separate and unequal school system in the United States of America.

And today, without the Federal Government being involved other than passing on to them, the school districts, the words from that commission, we find 35 States with task forces now dealing with their educational problems.

Recently his key economic adviser was asked about why he didn't seem to have some specific programs to help young people go to college and the response was, well, you know, we can't give money to every interest group that comes along.
We should have physical fitness programs and nutrition programs in schools.

You see, we'll never be able to compete in the 21st century unless we have an education system that doesn't quit on children, an education system that raises standards, an education that makes sure there's excellence in every classroom.
With half of college kids graduating this year without a college -- excuse me, without a job.

That's the access I believe is necessary, is to make sure every child learns to read, write, add and subtract early, to be able to build on that education by going to college so they can start their careers with a college diploma.
When it comes to community colleges, we are seeing great work done out there all over the country because we have the opportunity to train people for jobs that exist right now.
Greatly expand character education funding so that public schools will teach children values, values which have stood the test of time.
We have, with our five-year plan for the leasing of offshore lands, proposed more land to be drilled than has been opened up for drilling since this program first started in 1954.
Let's take advantage of the energy resources we have, as well as the energy sources for the future.
So across the board, we are engaging them in building capacity in these countries.
And that's why we've got to make some investments and I've called for investments in solar, wind, geothermal.
Let's just talk about the CAFE standards -- that's the fuel efficiency standards.
Number one, make sure that other countries are as open to our markets as our markets are to them, and, if they're not, have measures on the books that don't take forever and a day to implement.
Uh - We're using about fifty percent of our steel capacity today.

I think we need to get serious about this energy crisis, both in the Congress and in the White House, and if you entrust me with the presidency, I will tackle this problem and focus on new technologies that will make us less dependent on big oil or foreign oil.
We are exporting more coal this year than any year in history.
We are energy independent for the first time.
In my program for energy independence we have increased, for example, solar energy research from about $84 million a year to about a hundred and twenty million dollars a year.
I did it as a security measure to be sure, because I would rather see us reduce the consumption of imported oil than have to send American boys to fight in the Persian Gulf.
I'm not so sure that it means steadily higher fuel costs, but I do believe that this nation has been portrayed for too long a time to the people as being energy-poor when it is energy-rich.
We need to concentrate our research and development effort on uh coal burning and extraction, with safer mines, but also it's clean burning.
In addition to that, we ought to have a - a shift toward the use of coal, particularly in the Appalachian regions where the coal is located.

We've got an energy bill on the Senate floor right now that contains some good stuff, some stuff you want, including drilling off-shore, but you're opposed to it because it would strip away those tax breaks that have gone to oil companies.
If the president's energy policies are working, you're going to see the cost of energy come down.
So, if you buy a battery in this country, you buy a solar panel, it's being produced in a plant in China powered by coal where it's being powered by oil and gas at 20 percent off.
Our country is losing so much in terms of energy, in terms of paying off our debt.
But understand, we only have three to four percent of the world's oil reserves and we use 25 percent of the world's oil, which means that we can't drill our way out of the problem.
It was an energy bill on the floor of the Senate loaded down with goodies, billions for the oil companies, and it was sponsored by Bush and Cheney.
Because the president cut in half the number of licenses and permits for drilling on federal lands, and in federal waters.
But we need much more than wind and solar.
We need to shift from oil to coal.
And I support moving toward more clean, renewable energy as quickly as we can, because I think we can be the 21st century clean energy superpower and create millions of new jobs and businesses.
Perhaps that oil abroad should be treated differently than the oil here at home.
We have the best, lowest number in carbon emissions, which is a big standard that I noticed Obama goes with all the time.
After all, a lot of the energy is produced from the Middle East, and so I appreciate what the administration is doing.
Now, look, I'm a great believer in all forms of energy, but we're putting a lot of people out of work.
I want to develop the coal resources in America.

And it is absolutely critical that we understand this is not just a challenge, it's an opportunity, because if we create a new energy economy, we can create five million new jobs, easily, here in the United States.
We actually do give it to solar and wind--
We imported today 2 million barrels of oil less than we did the same date just a year ago.
They were already having a tough time because of high gas prices.

I think that, with respect to housing, when we are consuming, even though our per capita income today is about the same as that of the Federal Republic of Germany, we are consuming about, by a factor of two, the amount of energy that they consume in that country.
And that additional 15 million barrels is going to cause scarcity.

And if we're not making investments in education and basic research, which is not something that the private sector is doing at a sufficient pace right now and has never done, then we will lose the (inaudible) in things like clean energy technology.

Gas is a clean fuel that we can burn to -- we need to make sure that if we decontrol our plants that there's mandatory -- that the plants must conform to clean air standards, the grandfathered plants, that's what we did in Texas.
But don't forget, you put $90 billion, like 50 years' worth of breaks, into -- into solar and wind, to Solyndra and Fisker and Tester and Ener1.
Uh - Mr. McGee, there are about a hundred and four commodities that have some kind of depletion allowance - different kind of minerals, including oil.
But if you want to kill the economy, get rid of your oil industry.
And we knew where the fuel rods were.
I will fight for oil, coal and natural gas.
And we're going to get the great entrepreneurial spirit of this country, and we're going to free ourselves from this dependency on Mideast oil.
The offshore drilling rights is a question that Governor Reagan raises often.
